name: Explorer Operations
description: Master direct contract interaction to operate the protocol without any UI
graduationStandard: Execute a withdrawal via blockchain explorer

lessons.title: Reading Contract State
lessons.objective: Query view functions to read Vault data directly from the blockchain

sections.content: Every smart contract exposes view functions - read-only methods that don't change state. On Etherscan, go to Contract -> Read Contract. You can query ownerOf(tokenId) to see who owns a Vault, balanceOf(address) for Vault count, and getCollateral(tokenId) for current collateral amount.

View functions are free - no gas required. Enter the parameters (usually a tokenId or address), click Query, and the result appears. This is how you verify any claim about the protocol. Don't trust screenshots - read the chain directly.

content: Verify claims by reading the chain directly

questions.question: How do you verify a claim about Vault ownership?

practicalExercise.description: Read the collateral amount for a specific Vault tokenId
practicalExercise.verificationHint: Go to VaultNFT contract -> Read Contract -> getCollateral -> enter tokenId

sections.content: Function signatures describe what a function does and what inputs it needs. withdraw(uint256 tokenId) takes one input - the Vault ID. mintVestedBTC(uint256 tokenId) separates collateral. grantDelegation(address delegate, uint256 percentage) sets up withdrawal delegation.

Common types: uint256 = big number (token IDs, amounts), address = 42-character hex string (0x...), bool = true/false. Amounts are usually in wei (18 decimals) - 1 ETH = 1000000000000000000 wei. Check the ABI or documentation for expected formats.

questions.question: How is 1.5 BTC typically represented in smart contracts?

lessons.title: Executing Transactions
lessons.objective: Call write functions to modify state via Etherscan

sections.content: Write functions change blockchain state and require gas. On Etherscan, go to Contract -> Write Contract -> Connect to Web3 (connect your wallet). Fill in parameters and click Write. Your wallet will prompt for signature and gas payment.

Before executing: double-check parameters (wrong tokenId = failed tx). Verify you have enough ETH for gas. Review the transaction in your wallet before signing. After execution, get a transaction hash to track confirmation.

questions.question: What do you need before executing a write function?
How do you track a submitted transaction?
options: Use the transaction hash on Etherscan

practicalExercise.description: Execute any write function (even a simple approval) via Etherscan
practicalExercise.verificationHint: The transaction should appear in your wallet's transaction history

lessons.title: Event Interpretation
lessons.objective: Find and interpret contract events (logs) for transaction history

sections.content: Events are logs emitted by contracts when significant actions occur. Withdrawal(tokenId, amount, recipient) logs every withdrawal. Transfer(from, to, tokenId) logs NFT transfers. Events are indexed and searchable - useful for building history.

On Etherscan, click a transaction -> Logs tab to see emitted events. You can also use the Events tab on a contract to see all historical events. Decode the data using the ABI to understand what happened.

questions.question: Where do you find events for a specific transaction?
What is the purpose of events?
options: Log significant actions for history and indexing

practicalExercise.description: Find a Withdrawal event and decode its parameters
practicalExercise.verificationHint: Search for Withdrawal events on the VaultNFT contract's Events tab

lessons.title: Full Independence
lessons.objective: Execute a complete withdrawal flow without using any UI

sections.content: You now have all the skills to operate independently. The complete flow: 1) Read your Vault's tokenId from ownerOf queries or events. 2) Check getCollateral(tokenId) for current amount. 3) Verify lastWithdrawal to ensure cooldown passed. 4) Call withdraw(tokenId). 5) Verify via Withdrawal event.

This independence is the ultimate trust guarantee. No website can censor you. No frontend bug can block you. No hosting issue can lock your funds. As long as Ethereum runs, you can access your Vaults directly. This is true decentralization.
